Purpose

The Purpose of the residency is for talented programmers, writers, teachers etc. to come to London and live and work for Viral Academies. In the long run the goal is to establish a network of locations around Europe where people can move and live at low cost, while being able to work and gain some experience.

The idea would be to establish a support network across various locations in Europe, including London, Paris, Berlin, Stockholm and Ireland. This will give programmers, developers and writers who share various interests and projects in common a place to stay in each of these locations. It provides a kind of buffer for entrepreneurs who need time to develop particular ideas but do not yet have the resources to do so.
Compensation

We will establish a time-banking system between us where we can trade hours worked. If I contribute, I will earn time-chits, and if I take I will spend them. We will set up and agree to the parameter within which these will work. This includes but is not limited to 15 hours of work devoted to building the Viral Academy and helping to get it off the ground. Channels of contact are open almost all the time, and we are using the Slack app to communicate as a team as well as Asana to organize projects and video-conferencing. Ksenia is helping from Stockholm. David has set up a Harvest time-tracking app to track time in order to delineate actual work for the project from my own projects or just general research and self-education.

On Monday 9th of February I began a four-week residency in the apartment of David Bovill. The intention was to help him build Viral Academies and to produce content for the federated wikis. I would essentially act as a "crypto-journalist" and record my time and productivity using GetChime and a page in the wikis. This was essentially an experiment in the idea and this is an account of it.
How I Found the Residency
The main advantage for me as a writer and entrepreneur was to have a place to stay in London where I could network

The main advantage for me as a writer and entrepreneur was to have a place to stay in London where I could network and develop ideas, in return for the work. Because we were at the beginning stage of the residency I was not paid any cash, but in future this would be a good idea for future residents in London to be paid at least a small amount of cash- even 50 or 100 pounds a week, in order to be able to live in London and move and network. The biggest value of living in London for a prospective entrepreneur is networking and this requires money.

Overall I learned some things I didn't know before, particularly the methodology of federated wikis and was able to question David about some of his experience in programming and business which was of benefit.

The main advantage for me as a writer and entrepreneur was to have a place to stay in London where I could network and develop ideas, in return for the work. Because we were at the beginning stage of the residency I was not paid any cash, but in future I think it would be a good idea for future residents in London to be paid at least a small amount of cash- even 50 or 100 pounds a week, in order to be able to live in London and move and network. It is also psychologically important not to be trapped to the flat. The biggest value of living in London for a prospective entrepreneur is networking and this requires money.

The agreement for work hours was related to actual writing, including but not limited to 15 hours of work devoted to building the Viral Academy and helping to get it off the ground. Channels of contact are open almost all the time, and we are using the Slack app to communicate as a team as well as Asana to organize projects and video-conferencing. Ksenia is helping from Stockholm. David has set up a Harvest time-tracking app to track time in order to delineate actual work for the project from my own projects or just general research and self-education.

We are providing a series of month long residencies in London, and are looking to partner with other spaces to provide a network of spaces. Each space should provide good internet, and access to meetups and local organisations that share our aims.
